title: 110_s3539
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Girl Scouts USA Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". Congress acknowledges the Girl Scouts of the United States of America as a leading organization for girls, founded by Juliette Gordon Low in 1912 with the help of Sir Robert Baden-Powell. Low started the first 2 Girl Scout Troops in Savannah, Georgia and dedicated 15 years to building the organization. She also drafted the Girl Scout laws. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America was chartered by Congress in 1950. Currently, there are over 3.7 million members in 236,000 troops across the US and territories. The organization is part of a global family of 10 million girls and adults in 145 countries. Over 50 million American women have enjoyed Girl Scouting during their childhood. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America has over 3.7 million members in 236,000 troops across the US and territories. The organization is part of a global family of 10 million girls and adults in 145 countries. March 12, 2012 will mark the 100th Anniversary of the establishment of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 350,000 $1 silver coins in commemoration of the Girl Scouts centennial. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted for the Girl Scouts centennial will symbolize the establishment of the organization. The coins will feature the coin's value, the year 2011, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Girl Scouts and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may issue coins under this Act only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2011. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in section 7, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be made at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount as well. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.

All sales of coins minted under this Act shall include a $10 surcharge per coin, with the proceeds going to the Girl Scouts of the United States of America for their Centennial efforts, including preserving Juliette Gordon Low's birthplace. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the Girl Scouts' expenditure of these funds.
